title: Classes: Summary
question: Which of these are true about classes?
hint: The four differences between classes and structs are inheritance, copying, deinitializers, and mutability.

correct.answer: One class can inherit from another class.
A child class can override a method from its parent class.
correct.reason: Swift requires that we use the override keyword to make this clear.

correct.answer: You can declare a class as final to stop subclasses of it being created.
Deinitializers run when an instance of a class is destroyed.
correct.reason: This happens only with classes, not with structs.

correct.answer: Two variables can point at the same class data.
Classes and structs treat mutability differently.

wrong.answer: Structs can also use inheritance, but only in special circumstances.
You may inherit from multiple classes if you want.
wrong.reason: Swift supports inheriting from only one class.

wrong.answer: The override keyword must be used in all methods of a child class.
wrong.reason: This keyword must be used only for methods that exist on a parent class.

wrong.answer: Classes do not have access control keywords such as private
wrong.reason: They have the same access control keywords as structs.
They only need initializers if you don't give their properties default values.

wrong.answer: If you want others to inherit from your classes, you must mark it nonfinal
wrong.reason: The default behavior of classes is to be open for inheritance.
